Another problem is, it looks quite similar to amber.
During the world wars, a few bombs containing white phosphor were dropped in the Baltic See.
Now, after all the years, the metal of the bomb has corroded away, and the phosphor is released into the water. Occasionally, a piece of it will be carried to the beaches of the Baltic See.
And here comes the problem, because it looks so similar to amber, it's possible for a tourist to find a bit of white phosphor, and think it's amber. If you then put it in your pocket, the phosphor will dry, and because your pockets are getting heated by your skin, the phosphor will easily reach 30°C and ignite itself. And I'm sure we all can agree that nobody wants to have burning white phosphor in his or her pocket.
For this reason, on some beaches at the German Baltic coast, you will find signs warning you not to collect anything that looks like amber.

Interesting side note: when WWI ended, tons of incenidary bombs containing white phosphorus were dumped into the Baltic Sea. These things have been rotting and releasing white phosphorus, which when it turns yellow-orange, looks a lot like Baltic Amber. There are many cases of people mistaking phosphorus with amber, picking it up on the beach and their pants lighting on fire some minutes or hours later. This happens all across the coasts of Germany, Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia and sometimes Finland and Sweden

White phosphorus was used in WWII during the D-day landings. Rockets and shells hitting the German bunkers didn't penetrate the structure, but upon impact would scatter the phosphorus and it would enter through the gun slits. The accounts of the soldiers inside were horrific. They didn't know what it was that was catching everything on fire. Soldiers clothing was burning and they couldn't put it out, it just seemed to escalate no matter what they tried. Men were screaming being burned alive and the smoke was so thick they couldn't find the door to get out. Any exposed ordinance would explode and everyone was panicking from heat, smoke, explosions, the screams of the dying, and the smell of burning flesh. One surviving soldier said he was trapped in Hell with no way out and had no recollection of how he made it out alive.

I spent four years in the Regular Army, including time on the DMZ in Korea and two tours in Vietnam. We never used Willie Peter rounds as weapons. We used it to determine where artillery rounds would fall. Sort of a low tech range finder. Yes, if some got on an enemy, it burned. Doing that was NOT our goal. Once we had the correct range, we wanted to kill enemies quickly with HE (High Explosive) rounds. Our plan was never to wound them with burns; it was to kill them quickly with shrapnel. In an asymmetric war, the weaker side uses stealth and improvised weaponry to make surprise raids on the stronger and inflict casualties. The stronger side uses superior technology and logistics to concentrate massive destructive power on a designated area. The stronger side can also occupy and control more and more of the infrastructure, while denying it to an enemy. It is a war of attrition, in which the stronger side can always win; provided they have the political will to stay the course and keep making life more and more unbearable for the population supporting the enemy. The weaker side can win, if they are willing to endure crippling attacks, tremendous losses and to live in the woods sleeping on, or under, the ground, often for years. Si vis pacem para bellum.

The phosphorous you have is red phosphorous.  The white form slowly turns into red form on aging (you indicate that the sample is old).  To do this experiment properly, you need to melt the phosphorous in the absence of air, then let it totally cool.  This will convert it to the white form.  Then repeat the exercise (cutting off a chunk).  This should ignite spontaneously, even though it is cool.  The whole stick may ignite, so I would do the cut under water, then pick the piece out.

I used to make the stuff years ago at an elemental phosphorus plant in Pocatello Idaho. While employed there I worked  in the phos department as a furnace tapper, technician, and furnace chief as well as other jobs. Watching that burn demonstration I could almost sense the smell of that sample as the smoke has a very distinct odor.....at first I thought you had some false phos in the jar as it was common to have some fake stuff for visual demo purposes, and it looked very much the same as the real stuff did. I'm surprised you have some of the real stuff since its was federally deemed a controlled substance as its one of the main ingredients in making methamphetamine (an illegal drug). It looks like what you have was what we called red phos I've seen yellow phos which was termed white phos and from a pilot gas slip stream project, that produced some very purified phos that was as clear as water in its liquid state, so clear in fact you had to look close to see the separation line while viewed in a test tube. It was referred as pharmaceutical grade. You wouldn't believe the shit I saw at that plant it was like if you could imagine working on a different planet. The place just consumed your life... we worked 12 hr shifts and sometimes 16s it was very hot and dirty backbone work. I was around that shit all the time and at one time was a sump pumper for a time and that's all I did was pump the four sumps that belong to these four giant electric smelter furnaces. FYI luckily the most I got burned was a hot coke ball that come out of a tap hole while metal tapping a furnace and it burned through my fire retardant jacket and burned my forearm I still have that scar about the size if a dime, but I saw people there who been burned by phos and their scars were disfiguring healed like melted skin. It was known that if you were ever burned by the stuff they sent you to a burn center,  there you would undergo debridement of the burned tissue depending on the severity, it involved repeated scrubbing of the wound with a nylon brush to remove the dead or contaminated area to promote healing and keep the nerves alive....a very painful process from what I heard. We always heard horror stories about it amongst us and at numerous safety meetings we attended.  What an awesome, and crazy place that was to work at. The plant closed in 2001 but I was hired back for the clean up process and it was like a ghost town there... a place no pun intended seared into my memory.

A little trivia:  Apparently, white phosphorus actually isn't a very effective incendiary agent due to the formation of phosphoric acid during combustion.  The acid forms a glassy layer on surfaces like wood.  This layer of phosphoric acid is fire retardant, hardly a desirable property in an incendiary weapon.  Having said that, the liquid incendiary bombs used by the RAF during WWII did contain a small amount of white phosphorus in addition to a napalm-like jelly composed of rubber and benzene, though the phosphorus served primarily as an ignitor, rather than as the principal incendiary agent.  Having said all that, I'm an historian rather than a chemist by training and I'd welcome any feedback from those more knowledgeable in chemistry than myself.  Love your videos, by the way.

white phosphorus is classified by the US military as a "smoke screen" to get around using it near civilian areas.   In 2009, the US military gave Israel white phosphorus chemical weapons.   The military grade white phosphorus is loaded into mortars at the Army facility in Pine Bluff Arkansas, the only location in the entire North American continent qualified to load white phosphorus into mortars and grenade weapons.   After providing these mortars to Israel, Israel loaded the fuses into these mortars, to make them detonate at higher altitudes.  The effect was that the mortars exploded over dense populated areas of the Gaza strip, and the results included horrific burns to hundreds of civilians.   Once the phosphorus comes in contact with human skin, it adheres and bonds to the skin, and doesn't stop burning until the phosphorus is completely consumed.    After the United Nations found out that Israel had used white  phosphorus on civilian areas of Gaza, Israel was forced to stop using it.

as bad as it is...there is one little trick you can all try at home (once or twice only) to see the truly glowing nature of phosphorous...I was shown this by my old chem professor..here's what you do: grab a box of matches, now carefully just tear off one side of the striker pad, of course it will come off with a layer of thin paper attached, that's fine. now, set a coin down on the table (larger the better) and place the striker pad on the coin, with the striker surface facing down onto the coin...now simply using a cigarette lighter gently light the corner of the striker, it should burn across with a bluish flame...all this does is condense the phosphorus vapor onto the surface of the coin..now turn out the lights (so this is best done at night) and just wipe your index finger across the coin and rub your index finger and thumb together lightly as if clicking your fingers, you will see exactly how well this works ! it is bugger all phosphorus but still wash your hands afterwards and you'll be just fine...I've done it years and years ago and I'm ok....now..sally forth!  sally forth ! ..get it?..(Evil Dead 3 joke)

Lucifer is another word for phosphorus. The Latin word corresponding to Greek Phosphorus is “Lucifer.” Phosphorus (Greek Φωσφόρος Phōsphoros), a name meaning “Light-Bringer”, is the Morning Star. When phosphorus is combined with the elements below and carbon, it forms our very DNA.  When combined with oxygen and hydrogen, carbon can form many groups of important biological compounds, including sugars, lignans, chitins, alcohols, fats, aromatic esters, carotenoids and terpenes. With nitrogen it forms alkaloids, and with the addition of sulfur it also forms antibiotics, amino acids, and rubber products. With the addition of phosphorus to these other elements, it forms DNA and RNA, the chemical-code carriers of life, and adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the most important energy-transfer molecule in all living cells.  Nucleotides are biological molecules that form the building blocks of nucleic acids (DNA and RNA). Each nucleotide has three components: a phosphate group, a five-carbon sugar, and a nitrogen-containing base. The phosphate groups and the sugars form the backbone of each strand of DNA or RNA. The phosphate is a component of DNA, RNA, ATP, and also the phospholipids that form all cell membranes. Phosphorus (Lucifer) is just the ‘spark’ in our DNA that makes us fire.
